nodes.label: GOYA
nodes.author of: Piedad (1774), Aníbal vencedor (1771), tapestry cartoons (1775-1792), prints after Velázquez (1778), Crucifixion (1780), San Bernardino de Siena (1781-83), The Duchess of Osuna (1785), The Dukes of Osuna (1787-88), Yard of lunatics (1794), Witches Flight (1797-98), Album A (c.1794-95), Album B (c.1795-97), Caprichos (1799), Allegory of Truth, Time and History (1800), The Family of Charles IV (1800), Clothed Maja (1802-05), Bandit stripping a woman (1808-12), The Burial of the Sardine (1808-12), Portrait of Antonia de Zárate (1810-11), Disasters of War (1810-15), The Second of May 1808 (1814), The Third of May 1808 (1814), Ferdinand VII (1814-15), Self-Portrait (1815), Tauromaquia (1816), Disparates (c.1816-19), Black Paintings (c.1819-23), Bulls of Bordeaux (1825), Portrait of Mariano Goya (1827)
nodes.in France: 1824-1828, Bordeaux. He visited Paris in Summer 1824
nodes.students: Felipe Arrojo; Asensio Julià; Rosario Weiss
nodes.portrayed by: Vicente López (1826, Prado); Francisco de Goya y Lucientes
nodes.curiosities: he became completely deaf after a serious illness in 1792-93
nodes.bibliography: Martin Schwander (ed.), Goya, exhibition catalogue, Beyeler Foundation, 2021; Janis Tomlinson, Goya: A Portrait of the Artist, 2020; Manuela B. Mena Marqués & José Manuel Matilla, Goya: dibujos. ‘Solo la voluntad me sobra’, 2019; Manuela B. Mena Marqués & José Manuel Matilla, Catálogo Razonado de Los Dibujos de Francisco de Goya, vol. 2 (1771-1792), 2018; Mena Marqués (dir.), Goya en tiempos de guerra, 2008; Andrew Schulz, Goya's Caprichos: Aesthetics, Perception, and the Body, 2005; Reva Wolf, Goya and the Satirical Print: in England and on the Continent, 1730-1850, 1994; Bozal, Goya y el gusto moderno, 1994; Tomlinson, Goya in the Twilight of Enlightenmen, 1992; Carreta Parrondo & Vega, Goya grabador, 1991; Águeda & Salas (eds.), Goya. Cartas a Martín Zapater, 1982; López Canellas, Diplomatario, 1981; Nigel Glendinning, Goya and his Critics, 1977; Pierre Gassier, The Drawings of Goya: The Complete Albums, 1973; Pierre Gassier & Juliet Wilson-Bareau, Goya: His Life and Work, 1971 (catalogue raisonné); Tomas Harris, Goya. Engravings and Lithographs, 1964
nodes.websites: Fundación Goya en Aragón https://fundaciongoyaenaragon.es/; Museo del Prado https://www.museodelprado.es/coleccion/artista/goya-y-lucientes-francisco-de/39568a17-81b5-4d6f-84fa-12db60780812; Real Academia de Historia https://historia-hispanica.rah.es/biografias/20790-francisco-de-goya-y-lucientes
nodes.Image source: New York, Metropolitan Museum, Self-portrait, drawing, 35.103.1

nodes.label: Javier Goya
nodes.portrayed by: Goya

nodes.label: Mariano Goya
nodes.image source: Portrait by Goya, 1827, Meadows Museum, Texas (67.03)

nodes.label: Zapater
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya y Lucientes (1780, 1790, 1797)
nodes.image source: Portrait by Goya, 1790, Museo de Arte de Ponce, Puerto Rico

nodes.label: Gumersinda
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya y Lucientes (1805, 1805, 1805-06)
nodes.image source: Portrait by Goya, 1805-06, private collection, Paris

nodes.label: F. Bayeu
nodes.masters: Juan Andrés Merklein; José Luzán; Antonio González Velázquez
nodes.students: Agustín Esteve; Juan Antonio Ribera; Buenaventura Salesa
nodes.author of: tapestry cartoons for the Real Fábrica de Tapices
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya y Lucientes (1795)

nodes.label: Federico Madrazo
nodes.in Paris: 1833 (1st trip; with Vicente Masarnau): he meets Baron Taylor and Adrien Dauzats; 1837-1839 (portrays Adrien Dauzats 1837): he benefits from contacts with Baron Taylor; 1838 commission from Louis-Philippe for painting 'Godofredo de Bouillon' for Versailles
nodes.address: 1833 Paris: Hôtel Bourbonne-Les-Bains (very close to Adrien Dauzat's)
nodes.author of: illustrations in El Artista; Godofredo de Bouillon proclamado rey de Jerusalén (1838, Galerie Batailles, Palais Versailles); Isabel II de España (1850); Doña Amalia de Llano y Dotres, Condesa de Vilches (1853); Carolina Coronado (c.1855); Eduardo Rosales (1867); El pintor Perugino Sensi (1873, Prado)
nodes.portrayed by: Raimundo Madrazo, 1875, Museo de Bellas Artes de Bilbao
nodes.works as: Director of RABASF in 1866; Pintor de Cámara of Isabel II; Director of the Prado Museum 1860-68 and 1881-1894; Senator
nodes.masters: Alberto Lista; Franz Xaver Winterhalter; Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres
nodes.students: León Abadías y Santolaria; Ricardo Villodas y de la Torre
nodes.parents: José Madrazo and Isabel Kuntz y Valentini
nodes.image source: portrait by Raimundo Madrazo, 1875, Museo de Bellas Artes de Bilbao

nodes.label: Carderera
nodes.mentions of Goya: 1835 in El Artista (with lithography by Madrazo: Vicente López's portrait of Goya); 1860; 1863 (quotes Gautier's essay on Desastres 1845)

nodes.label: José Madrazo
nodes.in Paris: in 1829 (1st trip): sees Eugène Delacroix's work
nodes.works as: Pintor de Cámara of Carlos IV; reorganises and catalogues the collections of the Prado Museum; 1823 teacher of painting at the RABASF and Deputy Director
nodes.editor of: a catalogue of the Prado collection with lithographic illustrations of the paintings (made by Pharamond Blanchard)
nodes.collector of: a valuable painting collection, partly acquired by José de Salamanca y Mayol (I Marqués de Salamanca)
nodes.students: Léon Bonnat; José María Avrial y Flores; Pedro Kuntz y Valentini
nodes.author of: La muerte de Viriato (1807, Prado)
nodes.children: Federico Madrazo, Pedro Madrazo, Luis Madrazo, Juan Madrazo, Carlota Madrazo

nodes.label: Baron Taylor
nodes.in Spain: 1st trip in 1820; 1823 [Cien Mil hijos de S. Luis]; in 1832 (with Dauzats); July 1833 (with Dauzats): introduced to José Madrazo by Blanchard, portrayed by Madrazo; 1835-36 commissioned by Louis-Philippe to acquire paintings for Galerie espagnole (assisted by Dauzats and Blanchard, and benefited by active help and advice of Madrazo family and Carderera [Lanzarote Guiral 2016 p.574]): 1836 Feb-Aug paintings (8 Goyas from Javier Goya)
nodes.author of: Voyage pittoresque en Espagne, en Portugal et sur la côte d’Afrique, de Tanger a Tétuan (1826)

nodes.label: Dauzats
nodes.in Spain: in 1832 (with Baron Taylor); July 1833 (with Baron Taylor); 1835-1837 assists Baron Taylor in acquisition of artworks for Galerie espagnole (alongside Pharamond Blanchard)
nodes.author of: 1834 article in Magasin pittoresque? (mentions Prado commentaries, in the possession of Javier Goya until 1861)

nodes.label: Blanchard
nodes.in Spain: 1824-1837 working as a painter and engraver; hired by José Madrazo to make lithographic reproductions at the Real Museo in Madrid; 1835-37 he assists Baron Taylor in acquiring paintings for Louis Philippe's Galerie espagnole
nodes.in Paris: after 1837 (quoted by Carderera's diary) (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.537)
nodes.author of: 'Course de taureaux dans un bourg d'Espagne' (Salon 1834)
nodes.image source: AI generated (DeepAI) because there is no known portrait

nodes.label: Eugenio Ochoa
nodes.in Paris: 1828-1834 at the École d'Arts et d'Offices. He meets Moratín and Godoy; 1837-1845
nodes.author of: Translation of Victor Hugo's Hernani (watched by Théophile Gautier in 1840 in Valladolid); 'Catálogo razonado de los manuscritos españoles existentes en la Biblioteca Real de París: seguido de un suplemento que contiene los de las otras tres bibliotecas públicas' (Arsenal, Ste Geneviève and Mazarine), París, Imprenta Real, 1844
nodes.editor of: El Artista (1835) con Federico Madrazo: spreads Romanticism in Spain and imitates the French journal L'Artiste

nodes.label: Mérimée
nodes.visits the Prado Museum: in 1830 (doesn't mention Goya in his account)

nodes.label: Iriarte
nodes.works for: Fernando VI, Carlos III, Carlos IV, José I
nodes.member of: Real Academia Española; Real Academia de Ciencias y Artes de Barcelona
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya y Lucientes, 1797, Strasbourg Museum of Fine Arts

nodes.label: Delacroix
nodes.author of: Scenes from the Massacre at Chios (1824, Louvre), The Death of Sardanapalus (1827, Louvre), Liberty guiding the People (1830, Louvre)
nodes.knows Goya's works: by c.1819, through Ferdinand Guillemardet (Lipschutz 1972, p.10)

nodes.label: Brugada
nodes.curiosities: he sees Goya die in Bordeaux, alongside Molina (Canellas, Diplomatario,  no.181, p.512)
nodes.image source: AI generated (DeepAI) because there is no known portrait

nodes.label: Ceán Bermúdez
nodes.considered as: part of the group of Spanish 'ilustrados'
nodes.works as: manager of the Archivo de Indias; Secretary's officer for the Estado de Gracia y Justicia de Indias
nodes.author of: Colección lithographica de cuadros del Rey de España el Sr. D. Fernando VII (1826-37); Diccionario histórico de los más ilustres profesores de las Bellas Artes en España (1800); Sumario de las antigüedades romanas que hay en España, en especial las pertenecientes a las Bellas Artes (1832, postumous)
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya y Lucientes, 1785 (private collection)
nodes.collector of: Dürer, José de Ribera, Piranesi, among others
nodes.married to: Manuela Camas y de las Heras

nodes.label: Moratín
nodes.mentions of Goya: Diary, 21 May 1798 (Canellas no.88): they see together the paintings of San Antonio de la Florida?

nodes.label: Gaulon
nodes.portrayed by: Goya, 1824-25, lithography (Harris 1964, no.282)

nodes.label: Matheron
nodes.writes about Goya: first biography of Goya, 'Goya', 1858, París, Schulz et Thuillié (digitised in Prado Biblioteca https://www.museodelprado.es/aprende/biblioteca/biblioteca-digital/fondo/goya/47f25eaf-29e1-dd74-6727-6227f053e2a2)
nodes.image source: AI generated (DeepAI) because there is no known portrait

nodes.label: Aguado
nodes.Full name: Alejandro María Aguado y Remírez de Estenoz
nodes.profession: banker, military member, collector, patron of arts
nodes.collection: formed from two collections: that of Bernardo de Iriarte and the Count of Altamira (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.LV). Around 360 paintings, mainly by Spanish artists, including Velázquez, Murillo, Ribera and Zurbarán, as well as Italians like Leonardo da Vinci, Rafael, and Dutch-Flemish like Rubens and Rembrandt
nodes.patronage: acquired the Théâtre-Italien (or Comédie-italienne), funded the journals Revue de Paris and Le Constitutionnel, acted as the President of the Athénée des arts
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco Lacoma y Fontanet, 1832 (Madrid, Museo del Romanticismo, CE0509); unknown artist (Palais de Versailles, MV 6727)
nodes.aristocratic titles: I marqués de las Marismas del Guadalquivir

nodes.label: Devéria
nodes.works as: director of the Département des Estampes at the BNF in 1849
nodes.address: 45 rue de Nôtre Dame des Champs (1833)

nodes.label: Fontaney
nodes.shows Goya: Fontaney's journal (8 Sept 1831): 'Evening at l'Arsenal; Mélanie, Louise [Soulié] were there. I showed them the Goya' (ed. Jasinski 1925, p.31); 9 Nov 1831, at Belloc's: 'I am going to Mmes Belloc [Louise Swanton-Belloc], Mlle de Montgolfier [Adélaïde de Montgolfier]. (...) (Auguste) Blanqui the conspirator with a long white beard, (Jean-Alexandre) Plocque; (Auguste) Barthélémy;--a fat man who states in regard to Goya: It is not lacking in verve' (p.71)

nodes.label: Hugo
nodes.author of: Hernani 1830 (takes place in Spain)

nodes.label: Gautier
nodes.author of: 1840 Spanish trip essays in La Presse, reedited as Tra los montes (1843) and as Voyage en Espagne (1845). 1843 August: Gautier, ‘La Tauromachie’, Le Musée des familles, pp. 341–48.13 Illustrated with seven drawings by Gautier (signed ‘T. G.’) engraved by ‘A.B.L’ (Andrew, Best and Leloir) (see Fayos-Pérez 2024)
nodes.mentions of Goya: In 1831, 8 Sept: Albertus; 1832, 5 Aug, Onophrius Wphly, La France littéraire, pp.388-418: 'El sueno de la razon produce monstruos. Goya' (Capricho 43); 1834 preface of Mlle Maupin; 1838, 5 July, Les Caprices de Goya; (La Presse): mentions Goya's Album B of drawings?; ‘Franco Goya y Lucientes’, Le Cabinet de l’Amateur, 337–45 (with Valentín Carderera's help (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.550)); 1845 mentions Disasters of War (Voyage en Espagne, nouvelle édition révue, p.136) [quoted by Valentín Carderera in 1863] (see Fayos-Pérez 2024)
nodes.in Spain: in 1840 (with Piot), watches Hugo's Hernani (translated by Eugenio Ochoa; Gautier praises the translation)
nodes.knows Goya's works: Los Caprichos: in late 1830-late 1831 (Lipschutz 1972, p.118); through Antoine Fontaney? (brought Caprichos set in January 1831); Goya's drawings by 1838 (see Fayos-Pérez 2024)
nodes.collector of Goya's works: Bulls of Bordeaux; Tauromaquia (lot 66, 24-25 Feb 1873 sale): sold Sotheby's Paris, 14 Dec 2022, lot 37 (showing Valentín Carderera's dedicatory to Gautier)

nodes.label: Balzac
nodes.author of: La peau du chagrin (1831) mentions Murillo and Velázquez

nodes.label: Custine
nodes.author of: 1838, 17 June (Le Temps) essay on Goya's works (signed as 'A. de C.')
nodes.mentions of Goya: Letter to Miss Bowles (13 April 1831): 'Un peintre espagnol moderne, Goya, mérite d’être cité, surtout pour ses portraits. En mourant il a emporté la gloire et le secret de l’école de son pays. Sa manière tenait à la fois de celle de Velasquez et de celle de Murillo'; 1838 essay ('A. de C.'): Goya's Caprichos, Desastres, Toros Burdeos, Familia Carlos IV, frescoes and Black paintings (Fayos-Pérez 2025: publication pending)

nodes.label: Montgolfier
nodes.knows Goya's works: by April 1831, through Fontaney (after his return from Spain in Jan 1831)
nodes.writes about Goya: In April 1831: signed as 'Ad. M' (Revue encyclopédique no.50, pp.316-331)
nodes.author of: she co-authored with Louise Swanton Belloc a number of children's books (Buell Hale 1874, p.583-84)
nodes.founder of: La Ruche, journal d'études familière (with Louise Swanton Belloc), a monthly magazine dedicated to the education of young women (Buell Hale 1874, p.583-84)
nodes.curiosities: her father was the famous aeronaut Jacques-Etienne Montgolfier. She was buried alongside her close friend Louise Swanton Belloc (and her son, Louis Belloc) at La Celle-Saint-Cloud
nodes.bibliography: Sarah Josepha Buell Hale, Woman's Record: Or, Sketches of All Distinguished Women, 1874 https://books.google.es/books?id=X7ZiAAAAMAAJ&vq=belloc+la+ruche&hl=es&source=gbs_navlinks_s

nodes.label: George Sand
nodes.profession: writer, novelist, journalist, salonnière, art critic, playwright, libretist, composer
nodes.in Spain: 1808-1809 her family lived in Spain at the palace of Manuel Godoy when this one was exiled in Paris
nodes.mentions of Goya: Journal intime, 25 Nov 1834 (jealousy over Goya's women regarding Alfred de Musset)
nodes.author of: Voyage chez Mr. Blaise (1829); Voyage en Auvergne (1829); Voyage en Espagne (1829); Un hiver en Majorque (1841); La Petite Fadette (1849); Histoire de ma vie (1855). Album of drawings. Clumsy copy of Velázquez’s Infanta Margarita. Collection Lovenjoul Chantily [now at Institut de France? (Lipschutz 1972, p.117)
nodes.parents: Maurice Dupin de Francueil and Sophie Victoire Delaborde
nodes.partners/lovers: Prosper Mérimée; Jules Sandeau; Alfred de Musset (1833-35); Félicien Mallefille; Frédéric Chopin; Victor Borie (1848-49); Alexandre Manceau (1849-64)

nodes.label: Burty
nodes.sales: Burty I: [11] Oct 1862; Burty II: 27 March 1874 (lot 14: 2 black pencil drawings by Delacroix after Goya, 13 fr.); Burty III: 27 April 1876 (Sotheby's London; 56 lots of Goya (nos.444-465, 684-719): Caprichos, Tauromaquia, Proverbios, Desastres, others; Burty IV (19-21 June 1878); Burty V (2-3 March 1891): lot 83 4 pen drawings by Delacroix after Goya; Burty VI (4-5 March 1891): Tauromaquia, Desastres, Proverbios, Agarrotado, drawing; Burty VII (16-20 March 1891)

nodes.label: N. Guye
nodes.profession: Military man; politician; Governor of the province of Seville during the French occupation

nodes.label: Vivant Denon
nodes.in Spain: 1808, acquiring artworks for the Musée Napoléon
nodes.collector of Goya's works: Los Caprichos (1809 in France; 1827 at the BNF)

nodes.label: Piot
nodes.profession: art critic; collector; editor; journalist; photographer
nodes.collector of Goya's works: Caprichos (in the 1840s); Bulls of Bordeaux; Tauromaquia
nodes.collection: started around 1838 during a trip to Italy. His interest in the arts started in relation to his friend Théophile Gautier. He acquired objects at the sales of Pourtalès (1865), Barre (1878) and Paravey (1879) (see Garnery 2023)
nodes.author of: Catalogue raisonné de l’oeuvre gravé de Fran(co) Goya y Lucientes, Le Cabinet de l’Amateur, 1842 (pp.346-366): Caprichos (80), Tauromaquia (33), Desastres de la guerra (‘Scènes d’invasion’) (20/82), prints after Velázquez (14), Pièces diverses (Garrotted Man), Lithographs (Bulls of Bordeaux) (6)
nodes.editor of: Le Cabinet de l'amateur et de l'antiquaire (1842-1846)
nodes.sales: 12 April 1847: Caprichos (bought by 'Bauzonnet'?), Tauromaquia (lots 29-30); 1848; 1850; 1857 and 1858 (dedicated to Egyptian, Greek and Roman antiquities); 1864; 1870; 1876; 1885, 22 rare proofs of Caprichos with handwritten inscriptions, acquired by BNF [Fayos Pérez 2024, p.55]; 1890 (posthumous)
nodes.mentions of the Prado commentaries: On his catalogue raisonné 1842 (Capricho 50):  Carderera’s diary (2 August 1861) shows he lent them to Piot, but he must have known them by 1842, having copied them in Madrid, or during one of Madrazo’s trips to Paris?
nodes.founder of: Le Cabinet de l'Amateur, illustrated by artists such as Eugène Delacroix and Ernest Meissonnier
nodes.member of: Société de l’histoire de France (1843); Société de l’histoire de Paris et de l’Île-de-France (1874-1881); Société nationale des antiquaires de France (1843); l’Institut archéologique de Rome (1865); Académie de Saint-Ferdinand [RABASF?] (1873)
nodes.address: Impasse du Doyenné; 20, rue Saint-Fiacre; 64, rue de Courcelles (after 1860)
nodes.curiosities: in his 1840 trip to Spain, Piot took photographs of the Burgos cathedral
nodes.bibliography: Lucille Garnery, Des bizarrerie du marché de l’art : les rachats Piot lors de ses propres ventes, 2023 [https://venteantique.hypotheses.org/4531]; Edmond Bonnafé, Eugène Piot, 1890; Charlotte Piot, Eugène Piot, amateur d'art et collectionneur; Louis Courajod, Eugène Piot et les objets d'art légués au Louvre, Gazette des Beaux-arts, pp.395-425

nodes.label: Vicente López
nodes.works as: Pintor de Cámara of Isabel II
nodes.author of: portrait of Francisco de Goya y Luciantes, 1826 (Prado); portrait of Fernando VII con el hábito de la Orden del Toisón de Oro, 1831
nodes.students: Justo María de Velasco; José Ribelles
nodes.children: Bernardo López Piquer; Luis López Piquer
nodes.curiosities: his face showed in the 25-pesetas bill in 1931 (2nd Spanish Republic)

nodes.label: Lefort
nodes.collector of Goya's works: Large collection. He has Disparates' 'Fiero monstruo' (no.81), not included in the 1864 edition, to the RABASF in 1870
nodes.writes about Goya: Catalogue raisonné of Goya's prints, Gazette des Beaux-Arts, 1867-68
nodes.image source: AI generated (DeepAI) because there is no known portrait

nodes.label: Brunet
nodes.writes about Goya: 1865 Étude sur Francisco Goya sa vie et ses travaux : notice biographique et artistique
nodes.image source: AI generated (DeepAI) because there is no known portrait

nodes.label: Román Garreta
nodes.collector of Goya's works: 1866 sells to the Prado 3 works attributed to Goya: Self-portrait 1815 (GW 1552), Portrait of a woman (Leocadia Zorrilla or  Bayeu) (GW 686) and Exorcism (follower of Goya); a group of drawings; copperplates from Disparates (1854)
nodes.image source: AI generated (DeepAI) because there is no known portrait

nodes.label: Luisa Garreta
nodes.children: Luisa Madrazo, Raimundo Madrazo, Cecilia Madrazo, Ricardo Madrazo
nodes.portrayed by: Federico Madrazo, 1837 (private collection)

nodes.label: Leocadia
nodes.image source: AI generated (DeepAI) because there is no known portrait

nodes.label: Rosario Weiss
nodes.in Spain: back to Madrid in 1833: works by making copies of famous paintings; 1840 named member of Royal Academy of San Fernando; 1842 drawing teacher of future Isabel II
nodes.masters: Francisco de Goya y Lucientes, Pierre Lacour fils (in Bordeaux)

nodes.label: Josefa Bayeu
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya y Lucientes, c.1805, drawing, Colección Abelló, Madrid (GW.840)

nodes.label: S. Martínez
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya y Lucientes, 1792, New York, Metropolitan Museum (06.289)

nodes.label: Carresse
nodes.image source: AI generated (DeepAI) because there is no known portrait

nodes.label: Yriarte
nodes.works as: inspector of government buildings (by 1856); reporter for Le Monde Illustré during the Spanish campaign in Morocco ('Guerra de África'); editor of Le Monde Illustré in 1862
nodes.writes about Goya: Goya, sa vie, son œuvre (1867) (mentions Album A-B p.93)
nodes.knows Goya's works: he focused particularly on the Disasters of War print series
nodes.collector of Goya's works: Riña en el mesón del gallo (in his collection by 1867)
nodes.author of: La société espagnole, 1861
nodes.curiosities: he enlisted in the Spanish army to work as a war reporter and witnessed the 'African War' (1859-60)

nodes.id: José de Salamanca y Mayol (I Marqués de Salamanca)
nodes.label: Salamanca
nodes.sales: 1867-VI-5: Goya's Femme à l'éventail (no.177); 1869 (pieces acquired by the British Museum; pieces by José Madrazo); 1875

nodes.label: Baudelaire
nodes.author of: Salons (1845, 1846, 1859); Les Fleurs du mal (1857)

nodes.label: Récamier
nodes.portrayed by: Jacques-Louis David (1800, Louvre); F. Gérard (1805, Musée Carnavalet)

nodes.label: Stendhal
nodes.author of: Le rouge et le noir (1830)
nodes.portrayed by: Doucis, 1835
nodes.writes in: Journal de Paris, The New Monthly Magazine, The London Magazine
nodes.pseudonyms: Stendhal, Henri Stendhal, Stendalis, Louis Alexandre Bombet, Anastase de Serpière, Don Flegme, William Crocodile, Dominique

nodes.label: Sainte-Beuve
nodes.author of: (Bad) criticism of Hugo, Lamartine, Musset, Baudelaire, Stendhal, Balzac

nodes.label: Flaubert
nodes.author of: Madame Bovary (1857); L'Éducation sentimentale (1869)

nodes.label: Swanton-Belloc
nodes.author of: the translations of 'Uncle Tom's Cabin' (1852) by Harriet Beecher Stowe, the memoirs of Lord Byron, the works of Walter Scott, and four works by Charles Dickens, among others. She also authored over forty books, including a life of Byron, published with an introduction by Stendhal. She co-authored with Adélaïde de Montgolfier a number of children's books (Buell Hale 1874, p.583-84)
nodes.participated in: a project after the 1830 Revolution to help General Lafayette establish public libraries in France, but it did not succeed (Buell Hale 1874, p.583-84)
nodes.founder of: La Ruche, journal d'études familière (with Adélaïde de Montgolfier), a monthly magazine dedicated to the education of young women (Buell Hale 1874, p.583-84)
nodes.curiosities: she was buried alongside her close friend Adélaïde de Montgolfier (and her son, Louis Belloc) at La Celle-Saint-Cloud. She was friends with Charles Dickens and Harriet Beecher Stowe. Her son would marry a prominent English feminist, Bessie Rayner Parkes, and they had two children who would become prolific writers: Marie Adelaide Belloc Lowndes (novelist) and Hilaire Belloc (poet and historian)
nodes.bibliography: Sarah Josepha Buell Hale, Woman's Record: Or, Sketches of All Distinguished Women, 1874 https://books.google.es/books?id=X7ZiAAAAMAAJ&vq=belloc+la+ruche&hl=es&source=gbs_navlinks_s

nodes.label: Staël
nodes.author of: Delphine (1802); Corinne ou l'Italie (1807) [these two novels are published in Spain before 1828]; De l'Allegmagne (1810-13); Considérations sur les principaux événements de la Révolution française (1818, posthumous)
nodes.correspondence: Correspondance générale, ed. Béatrice W. Jasinski and Othenin d'Haussonville, 2008-09
nodes.married to: Erik Magnus Stael (from 1786 to 1802); Albert de Roca (from 1811)
nodes.partners/lovers: Benjamin Constant (writer and politician) (from 1794); François de Pange (writer and journalist); Charles Maurice de Talleyrand; Louis, comte de Narbonne-Lara
nodes.children: Gustavine, Auguste, Albert, Albertine, Louis-Alphonse Rocca
nodes.curiosities: she was expelled from France by Napoleon I due to her political ideas (advocating for constitutional monarchy)

nodes.label: Pedro Madrazo
nodes.profession: writer, translator, scholar, journalist, art critic, painter
nodes.portrayed by: Federico Madrazo (1842, Hispanic Society); J. Laurent (BNE)
nodes.curiosities: one of the first people to ever use the term 'patrimonio histórico-artístico'

nodes.label: Juan Madrazo
nodes.author of: Palacio del Conde de Villagonzalo, Madrid
nodes.parents: José Madrazo and Isabel Kuntz y Valentini

nodes.label: Luis Madrazo
nodes.in Paris: lived there for a while. His work is recognised at the Exposition Universelle de Paris 1855
nodes.author of: Entierro de Santa Cecilia en las catacumbas de Roma (1852, Prado, deposit in Granada Museum)

nodes.label: Raimundo Madrazo
nodes.in Paris: in 1860 (disciple of Léon Cogniet); participates at the Exposition Universelle 1860 and 1889
nodes.collector of Goya's works: 1869 Perros y útiles de caza (tapestry cartoon), donated in 1894 to the Prado
nodes.portrayed by: Federico Madrazo (1875, Prado)

nodes.label: Cecilia Madrazo
nodes.portrayed by: Federico Madrazo (1869); Luis Madrazo (1880)
nodes.curiosities: she was a pianist; she lived in Madrid, Paris and Venice

nodes.label: Fortuny
nodes.author of: La batalla de Tetuán (1862-64); Viejo desnudo al sol (1863, Prado); La vicaría (1870)
nodes.portrayed by: Federico Madrazo (1867, Museo Nacional de Arte de Cataluña)

nodes.label: Viardot
nodes.participates in: the 'Expedition d'Espagne' or 'Cien Mil Hijos de San Luis' in 1823
nodes.author of: Lettres d'un espagnol (1826); Etudes sur l'histoire des institutions, de la littérature, du théâtre et des ­beaux-arts en Espagne (1835); longer essay on the Prado (Les musées d’Espagne, d’Angleterre et de Belgique) (1843); Les musées d'Espagne (1852)
nodes.visits the Prado Museum: in 1834 (mentions Goya in his account): 1835 publication
nodes.mentions of Goya: according to Pierre Géal (Viardot's profile, Prado): 'His opinion of Goya remains ambivalent, between praise for the strength and boldness of his brushstroke and reticence about the imperfections of the drawing'
nodes.writes in: journals Le Globe, Le National, Le Siècle; magazines Revue des Deux Mondes and Revue de Paris. In 1841 he founds the Revue Indépendante with Pierre Leroux and George Sand

nodes.label: Altamira
nodes.full name: Vicente Joaquín Osorio de Moscoso y Guzmán
nodes.considered as: part of the group of Spanish 'ilustrados'
nodes.works as: director and co-founder of the Banco de España; Gentilhombre de Cámra; Presidente de la Junta Suprema Gubernativa del Reino; Alférez mayor; Caballerizo mayor
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya y Lucientes, 1787 (Banco de España collection)
nodes.parents: Ventura Antonio Osorio de Moscoso y Fernández de Córdoba and María de la Concepción de Guzmán y de la Cerda
nodes.curiosities: after his father's death in 1776, he inherited a massive fortune and became one of the most powerful and richest men of his time. He catalogued his rich family library in 1789 with the librarian Pablo Recio. Altamira was particularly short, as commented by Lord Holland
nodes.websites: Real Academia de Historia (Adriano Gutiérrez Alonso) https://historia-hispanica.rah.es/biografias/33463-vicente-joaquin-osorio-de-moscoso-y-guzman

nodes.label: Jovellanos
nodes.considered as: part of the group of Spanish 'ilustrados'
nodes.political views: liberal. He was a key agent in the so-called 'reformismo ilustrado', especially regarding economic and cultural development. However, with the French Revolution he paralised the liberal ideas and removed from office any liberal thinkers. With the fall of his friend Francisco Cabarrús, Jovellanos left the Court and went into exile in 1790. He returned to politics in 1797 as Ministro de Gracia y Justicia and tried to reform the Justice system and decrease the influence of the Inquisition, but he resigned after 9 months. He went back to Asturias in 1798 and worked on the study of the Asturian language. In 1800 Manuel Godoy orders his arrest and he is exiled in Mallorca, imprisoned at the Real Cartuja de Jesús de Nazaret, then at the Castle of Bellver. Liberated in 1808, he refused to take part in José Bonaparte's government. He represented Asturias in the Junta Central
nodes.works as: Ministro de Gracia y Justicia (1797-98); contributed to the creation of Banco de San Carlos (1782)
nodes.author of: politics - Informe sobre la ley agraria (1784), Memoria sobre la educación pública, Memoria en defensa de la Junta Central; plays - El delincuente honrado (1773), Pelayo (1769); translations - Milton's Paradise Lost; diary and memoirs - facismile (Biblioteca Digital Hispánica https://bdh.bne.es/bnesearch/detalle/bdh0000014014), transcribed in Obras completas, II, 1857, 4th ed. (Biblioteca de Autores Españoles [https://www.cervantesvirtual.com/obra-visor/diario-mayo-1780-marzo-1808/html/ff6bab88-82b1-11df-acc7-002185ce6064_23.html]); travel diary from Bellver to Guadalajara (April-June 1808)
nodes.founder of: Real Instituto Asturiano de Náutica y Mineralogía in Gijón (1794), applying Enlightenment ideas
nodes.member of: RABASF (1780), Real Academia de la Historia (1779), Real Academia Española (1781)
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya y Lucientes, 1798 (Prado P003255); attribution to Antonio Carnicero, c.1797 (Museo Lázaro Galdiano)
nodes.studied in: Real Monasterio de Santo Tomás (University of Ávila)
nodes.correspondence: Obras completas, ed. José Miguel Caso González, 1985, 1986, 1988, 1990

nodes.label: Floridablanca
nodes.considered as: part of the group of Spanish 'ilustrados'
nodes.political views: he was a key agent in the so-called 'reformismo ilustrado', encouraging improvements in infraestructures, administration and economy (such as the creation of the Dirección General de Caminos, 1785). However, he opposed the ideas of the French Revolution and became more conservative; he implemented censorship and reinforced the Inquisition, controlling the border to avoid the spread of revolutionary ideas. External politics: he made Spain participate in the Independence War at the US against Great Britain, getting back the territories of Menorca and Florida. His rivals were Count of Aranda (more liberal and pro-Revolution) and Manuel Godoy (his successor)
nodes.works as: Primer Secretario de Estado (1777-92); Secretario de Gracia y Justicia (1782-90)
nodes.member of: Real Academia de Jurisprudencia y Legislación; Real Academia de Ciencias y Artes de Barcelona
nodes.portrayed by: Pompeo Batoni, c.1776 (Art Institute of Chicago); Francisco de Goya y Lucientes, 1783 (Prado P003255)
nodes.decorations / awards: Caballero de la Orden del Toisón de Oro; Orden de Carlos III
nodes.curiosities: Carlos III awards him with the title of Count of Floridablanca (1773) for his work as ambassador at the Holy See, contributing to the abolition of the Jesuit order

nodes.label: Cabarrús
nodes.profession: economist, banker, diplomat, politician, civil servant
nodes.considered as: part of the group of Spanish 'ilustrados' and 'afrancesado'
nodes.works as: Ministro plenipotenciario; Ministro de Hacienda (1808-10); Ministro de Finanzas with Joseph Bonaparte
nodes.political views: liberal. Political feuds. Imprisoned in 1790 for an alleged fraud. Afterwards he returns to politics with Carlos IV. Afrancesado during the Napoleonic invasion (named caballero Gran Banda de la Orden Real de España by Joseph Bonaparte); he is arrested in June 1808 in Zaragoza alongside Jovellanos; he then works for Joseph Bonaparte until his death in 1810
nodes.founder of: contributed to the creation of Banco de San Carlos in 1782; Real Compañía de Filipinas; Canal de Cobarrús (now Canal de Isabel II)
nodes.member of: Sociedad económica de amigos del país
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya y Lucientes, 1788 (Banco de España)
nodes.aristocratic titles: Count of Cabarrús (1789, Carlos IV); Grande de España
nodes.curiosities: he was buried in the Capilla de la Concepción at the Sevilla cathedral (during the Napoleonic War). After the war, his remains were exhumed and allegedly thrown in the common grave at the Patio de los Naranjos (with the victims of death penalty), or to the Guadalquivir river

nodes.label: Ingres
nodes.author of: Napoléon I (1806); Vœu de Louis XIII (Salon 1824); Portrait de Monsieur Bertin (Salon 1832)
nodes.in Italy: 1806-1824 (1801 Grand prix de Rome en peinture)
nodes.works as: directeur de l'Académie de France à Rome (1835-1842)
nodes.masters: Joseph Roques, Jean Suau, Jacques-Louis David (1796)
nodes.students: Amaury-Duval, Théodore Chassériau, Hippolyte Flandrin, Antoine Étex, Émile Hirsch, Romain Cazes, Louis Janmot, Alexandre Mauvernay, Charles Nègre, Clément Pruche, Henri Lehmann
nodes.curiosities: he was a violin player at the Orchestre de Toulouse

nodes.label: Daumier
nodes.author of: 4,000 lithographs, 1,000 woodcuts
nodes.works in: Le Charivari, La Silhouette, La Caricature
nodes.curiosities: Detained in the prison of Sainte-Pélagie (Paris) for the caricature Gargantua (1831)

nodes.id: J. J. Grandville (Jean Ignace Isidore Gérard)
nodes.label: Grandville
nodes.author of: Les Métamorphoses du jour (1829); Fables de La Fontaine (1838-40); Scènes de la vie privée et publique des animaux  (1842); Un autre monde (1844); Don Quichotte (1848)

nodes.label: Gros
nodes.students: Charles-Philippe Larivière, Paul Huet, Louis Léopold Robert
nodes.portrayed by: François Gérard (c.1790)

nodes.label: Delaroche
nodes.curiosities: his living descendants are named Delaroche-Vernet

nodes.label: Chopin
nodes.curiosities: he stated that in Mallorca 'The three most celebrated doctors on the island have seen me ... The first said I was dead, the second that I am dying, and the third that I'm going to die' (1962, ed. Bronisław Edward Sydow, p.164)

nodes.label: David
nodes.author of: Bonaparte franchissant le Grand-Saint-Bernard (1800, Malmaison); Mme Récamier [Juliette Récamier] (1800, Louvre)
nodes.students: Jean-Germain Drouais, Antoine-Jean Gros, Jean-Auguste-Dominique , Girodet, François Gérard, Marie-Guillemine Benoist, Jacques-Louis-Michel Grandin, José Madrazo
nodes.curiosities: Bonaparte franchissant le Grand-Saint-Bernard (1800) was commissioned by the Spanish king Charles IV (through the French ambassador Charles-Jean-Marie Alquier)

edges.portraits: 1812-14, private collection, Duke of Alburquerque, Madrid; 1827 Meadows Museum, Texas

edges.correspondence: Correspondence. 1824-XII-24: Goya wonders why Javier doesn't answer his letters; mentions Galos (Canellas no.271, p.388); 1828-I-17: mentions Galos, Mugurio and Esteve (no.277, p.392); 1828-III-12: mentions Mariano and Galos (no.279, p.393); 1828-III-26 (no.280, p.394)
edges.portraits: 1805 private collection, Casa Torres, drawing (GW.843); 1805, Museo de Zaragoza, miniature (GW.844); 1805-06, private collection, Paris, full portrait (GW.852); 1810-15 Boston MFA (GW.837); 1824 private collection, drawing (GW.1636)

edges.correspondence: 1765-1803. First letter: 1st letter in Diplomatario (Canellas López): 1774? (no.4); 6 Sept 1775 (no.7); 22 Jan 1777 (no.11); March 1777 (no.13); 16 April 1777 (no.14); 16 April 1777 (no.15); 21 Jan 1778 (no.17); 31 Jan 1778 (no.19); 7 Oct 1778 (no.21); Dec 1778 (no.23); 9 Jan 1779 (no.25); 25 Feb 1780 (no.29); 10 May 1780 (no.31); 17 May 1780 (no.32); 24 May 1780 (no.33); [21] July 1780 (no.34); 9 Aug 1780 (no.35); 16 Aug 1780 (no.36); 23 Aug 1780 (no.37); 23 Aug 1780 (no.37); ... (Bib: Cartas a Martín Zapater, ed. Águeda and Salas, 2003)
edges.portraits: Goya portrayed Zapater in c.1780 (private collection), 1790 (Museo de Arte de Ponce, Puerto Rico) and 1797 (Museo de Bellas Artes de Bilbao)
1805, Museo de Zaragoza, miniature (GW.845); 1805, drawing, lost (GW.841); 1805-06, private collection, Paris, full portrait (GW.851)

edges.correspondence: 28 Nov 1824: Goya tells Ferrer about Rosario, praising her artistic skills, asking F to host her in Paris for her to learn painting. No response from Ferrer

edges.they met: 1824 in Bordeaux (letter of Moratín to Melón, 30 Sept 1824, Canellas no.154)

edges.correspondence: 15 July 1826, letter of Moratín to Melón, from Bordeaux (Canellas no.174); July 1828, from Paris, letter of Moratín to Melón (Canellas no.173)

edges.relationship type: Vivant Denon acquired a set of the Caprichos in Spain c.1808

edges.they met: in Bordeaux (1824-28) at Pierre Lacour's establishment

edges.shared: coincided in Bordeaux. Goya probably asked Lacour to teach Rosario Weiss

edges.relationship type: business partners (sold a group of paintings attributed to Francisco de Goya y Lucientes in 1837 for the Galerie espagnole)

edges.children: Luisa Madrazo, Raimundo Madrazo, Cecilia Madrazo, Ricardo Madrazo

edges.they met: 19 Aug 1861 (Paris): with Baron Taylor and Eugenio Ochoa
edges.correspondence: 1837-XII-3, Paris, Madrazo to Carderera: Adrien Dauzats recommends Carderera, via Madrazo, to go to Paris ('de pensar venirse a Francia debe indudablemente  ser a París' (Bib: Lanzarote Guiral 2016 p.XXIII; Díez 1994, no.528, pp.988-89)

1856-VII-8 (Carderera archive): Mérimée answers he doesn't own a set of Goya's 'Toros' and he could buy a set if not too expensive; that he doesn't know the 'Proverbios' nor the 'suppressed Caprichos'(Fayos-Pérez 2020; Fayos-Pérez 2024 p.65)

edges.link to Goya's work: 1861 in Paris, C gives Blanc Goya prints (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.536)

edges.shared: correspondence. 1863-XI-5 (Carderera archive): mentions Goya's Caprichos, Tauromaquia, 'Scènes d'invasion' (Desastres) and 'Sueños o Proverbios' (Disparates) (Fayos Pérez 2020)

edges.correspondence: Not located (this correspondence exists according to Bonnaffé 1890, p.35)
edges.they met: 22 Nov 1842 (diary): Carderera reviews with Piot his notes on Goya (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.167); 24 Sept 1855: Carderera visits Piot's house (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.565); 13 July 1861 C shows P his drawings and Goyas'; 2 Aug 1861 C gives Piot the copies explanation of Goya (Prado commentaries) (ibid. p.454, 462; they also meet other times 1861: pp.453, 459, 464)
edges.collaborations: Carderera helped Piot with his Goya catalogue raisonné (1842), as well as Gautier
edges.mentions: Piot mentions Carderera and Agustín Ceán Bermúdez in his catalogue raisonné 1842 (p.346)

edges.they met: in Paris, Carderera visits Aguado's art gallery on 17 May 1841 (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.LV)

edges.relationship type: Aguado acquired a part of Altamira's collection (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.LV).
Aguado acquired a part of Iriarte's collection (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.LV)

edges.correspondence: 1794-I-4 Goya to Iriarte: the famous letter where Goya announces his small cabinet paintings out of commission, on topics drawn from the 'capricho e invención' (Canellas p.314, no.188; also no.189, 1794-I-7)
edges.they met: in Paris, Carderera visits Aguado's art gallery on 17 May 1841 (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.LV)

edges.they shared: artists and writers like Balzac, Rossini and Nerval participated in the meetings at the Aguado residence in Paris

edges.correspondence: 21 June 1857 (Carderera archive) (Fayos-Pérez 2020)

edges.mentions: Yriarte acknowledges Carderera, Zarco del Valle, Fco Zapater and Lefort ('nous ont aidé de leurs lumières et de leurs documents), 1867, Avant-propos

edges.they met: 1837-X-2 Carderera offers Taylor to sell 2 Morales paintings, via Federico Madrazo (letter Federico Madrazo to Baron Taylor, Bordeaux, 2 Oct 1837: Lanzarote Guiral 2016 p. XXIII; Porée 1907, p.296); 1841-V-5, Paris: Taylor invites him to the Comédie Française (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.XLIX, p.11); 1841 V 7, 9, 21; 1841 XI 21 (he introduces Ferdinand Denis); 1841 XII 19; 1842 I 2, 5-7, 13, 17; 1842 IV 10; 1842 VIII 28; 1842 IX 11, 24, 28, 30 (Baron Taylor sees a portrait); 1842-XI-27; 1843-I-8; 1845-V-6; 1845 X 12 (sees a Velázquez portrait 'in Vienna'); 1845 XI 12, 14, 15; 1855 X-9, XI 3, 25, 26; 1859-X-1; 1861 VII 19, 29, 31, VIII 7, 19, 20, 21, IX 21; in Antwerp
edges.artworks bought/sold: 1839: Taylor offers Carderera a deal to buy his drawings and texts (Adrien Dauzats as middleman)

edges.to: José de Salamanca y Mayol (I Marqués de Salamanca)

edges.collaborations: Madrazo hired Blanchard to make lithographic reproductions at the Real Museo in Madrid

edges.correspondence: 2 Oct 1837: Carderera offers Taylor to sell 2 Morales paintings, via Madrazo (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.XXIII; Porée 1907, p.296)

edges.collaborations: 1835-37 travelled together to Spain to acquire artworks for the Galerie espagnole; also for 'Voyages pittoresques de l'ancienne France'
edges.correspondence: 1837-VII-5 (Paris) Taylor to Dauzats: he laments that Dauzats's trip in Spain is not being more fruitful; 'Je désire bien vivement qu'il en soit autrement. M. Gautier vous accompagnait. Revenez très promptement' (coll. Claude Roger-Marx) (Guinard 1967, 'Dauzats and Blanchard', p.271); 1837-VII-15, Taylor to Dauzats (Paris): about Dauzats's Spanish trip; 1842-II-27 (London) Taylor to Dauzats: BNF MS NA FR 23192, f.176; quoted in Luxenberg 2008, p.195, note p.162] 'Je vous avais bien dit que Carderera deviendrait fou, quand il s'agirait des prix. Proposez lui 20 frs. par dessin et 5 francs pour chaque explication. Nous en prendrons pour la somme qui me conviendra'

edges.they met: in 1833 to visit the Louvre's department of sculptures with Federico Madrazo

edges.correspondence: 1846, 12 Aug: Delacroix asks Dauzats for Goya's lithographies ('Goya ou la mort, cher ami') (Delacroix - Joubin 1936, p.275)
edges.curiosities: Delacroix named Dauzats the executor of his will (Mainer and Enguita 1999, p.128)

edges.correspondence: 1847 Delacroix to Gautier: mention of 'eight small Goyas' of bullfighting at Mauroner’s gallery on 35 rue Laffitte. Adrien Dauzats mentions a Spanish painter and restorer called Bueno, who had brought the alleged Goyas from Madrid
edges.mentions: 24 Sept 1837, Gautier mentions Dauzats and Taylor in an article about the Galerie espagnole (La Presse, pp.1-2)

edges.they met: 1846 in Madrid: royal wedding (also Théophile Gautier)
1846 in Madrid: royal wedding (also Alexandre Dumas père)

edges.correspondence: yes

edges.mentions: Eugenio Ochoa criticizes Gautier: “la vergonzosa tutela literaria en que nos tienen hace tanto tiempo los novelistas de Tras-os-Montes”, y en una nota: “Así titula M. Th. Gautier su llamado Viaje a España, libro tan verídico, tan chusco como las flamantes cartas de M. Alejandro Dumas” (Eugenio Ochoa, “Doña Blanca de Navarra, crónica del siglo XV por D. F. Navarro Villoslada, Art. II”, Renacimiento, 1847, p.79) (Randolph 1966, p.55)

edges.know each other since: at least 1833 (with Federico Madrazo): visit of L'Artiste, which would inspire El Artista

edges.correspondence: 1857, Delacroix congratulates Matheron for the publication of his book on Goya; 2 artworks by Goya have entered the Louvre collections thanks to Matheron [INHA NUM 0554 (01)] (https://bibliotheque-numerique.inha.fr/idurl/1/6255)

edges.shared: co-founders of the Revue indépendante with Pierre Leroux in 1841

edges.correspondence: since 1838 (Burty 1880, t.I, p.235)

edges.mentions: Baudelaire: 'Delacroix was passionately in love with passion, but coldly determined to express passion as clearly as possible'
Gros about The Massacre at Chios (1824): 'a massacre of art'
Piot mentions Esteve as the author of the 2nd 'tirage'; from the Caprichos (Catalogue raisonné, Cabinet de l'Amateur, 1842, p.355)

edges.collaborations: Authors of Catalogue raisonné of Goya's prints, Cabinet de l'amateur, 1842

edges.correspondence: 1835-V-11 Boulanger to Hugo (Maison Victor Hugo)
edges.collaborations: Boulanger illustrates Les orientales (1829): Les Fantômes

edges.link to Goya's work: Upon his return from Spain in January 1831, Fontaney shows his Caprichos set in the Arsenal (Nodier's salon), 8 Sept 1831, to artists such as Gautier (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.41)

edges.shared: social circle of Nodier's salon at Arsenal and Victor Hugo's Cenacle

edges.mentions: Fontaney mentions Montgolfier in his journal, 9 Nov 1831: 'I am going to Mmes Belloc, Mlle de Montgolfier' when he shows the 'Goya' (Caprichos) (Fontaney's Journal, ed. Jasinski 1925, p.31)
Fontaney's journal, 9 Nov 1831: 'I am going to Mmes Belloc, Mlle de Montgolfier (...)' when he shows the 'Goya' (Caprichos) (Fontaney's Journal, ed. Jasinski 1925, p.31)

edges.know each other since: 1827, 27 June, (Ulrich Guttinguer, Correspondance générale, tome 1, p.411; Lacoste-Veysseyre 2014, p.347)

edges.relationship type: acquaintances; friends of Hugo's father (Léopold Hugo)

edges.shared: Same seminary school in Madrid by 1811 (College of Nobles)

edges.collaborations: Balzac suggests Gautier to collaborate in La Chronique de Paris; Gautier is the author of one of the 1st biographies of Balzac
edges.mentions: Gautier: 'Je travaille à La Chronique de Paris qui est maintenant dirigée par Balzac qui est un bon gros porc très plein d’esprit et très agréable à vivre' (letter of Gautier to  E. de Nully, 1836)
edges.curiosities: Gautier tried to introduce Balzac in the world of drugs ('paradis artificiels') but Balzac preferred coffee (https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balzac_face_aux_%C3%A9crivains_de_son_si%C3%A8cle)

edges.collaborations: trip to Spain; authorship of Goya's catalogue raissonné 1842
edges.correspondence: 1842 [Aug?] Gautier asks Piot to borrow his 'Toromaquia' (Tauromaquia): ‘Prête-moi la Toromaquia pour un instant, après je t’appartiens’

edges.they met: 1846 in Madrid: royal wedding (also Pharamond Blanchard)

edges.linked to Goya's work: By 1871: Gautier saw Burty's working proofs of Disasters of War (Fayos-Pérez 2024, p.54; Gautier, 2 Feb 1871; Delesalle 1983, p.104)

edges.know each other since: the early 1830s; in 1835 in Vienna (Custine meets Mme Hanska)
edges.correspondence: since at least 1838; Balzac attended Custine's salon (https://nl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astolphe_de_Custine); Aug-Sept 1838: Balzac mentions to Custine a 'disparate féminin, qui est masculin' (reference to Goya's Disparates) (Fayos Pérez 2025, publication pending)

edges.bibliography: Marcel Bouteron, 'L'amitié de Balzac et de Stendhal', Revue des Deux Mondes, July 1941, pp.95-

edges.mentions: Baudelaire admired Balzac as a 'visionnaire passionné': 'Tous ses personnages sont doués de l'ardeur vitale dont il était animé lui-même. Toutes ses fictions sont aussi profondément colorées que les rêves […] bref, chacun dans Balzac, mêmes les portières, a du génie. Toutes les âmes sont des âmes chargées de volonté jusqu'à la gueule'
Gautier mentions Nodier's Histoire du roi de Bohême (1830), Le Figaro, 19 Oct 1836, 'Les récréations du génie' (Lacsote-Veysseyre 2014, p.218)

edges.bibliography: Bénichou, Romantismes français t.I, ed. 2004, p.9

edges.they met: 1835 in Vienna with Honoré de Balzac

edges.correspondence: Yes. (Lettres de Madame de Staël à Madame de Récamier, Paris, Domat, 1952)

edges.to: J. J. Grandville (Jean Ignace Isidore Gérard)

edges.from: J. J. Grandville (Jean Ignace Isidore Gérard)

edges.relationship type: influenced by Goya, from c.1819 (see Fayos Pérez 2024)
